Important Salesforce Terminology


(Click on the underlined text below for a screencast video.)


  • Account - a district, school, or organization.
  • Contact - a person who works for an Account.
  • Lead - a person who has interacted with ARC generally, but not an Account Manager specifically. Example: webinar attendee
  • Opportunity - a potential deal that is moving through the DELC pipeline stages.
    • Quote - variations of the Opportunity, if needed. An Opportunity can have multiple Quotes.
    • Product - the individual line items contained in a Quote. Example: 100 Book Challenge Module
  • Calendar (and Event) - a Calendar is a list of the Events occurring on a Salesforce user's calendar. Salesforce and Outlook calendars can be synchronized. An Event is a meeting on a Calendar involving, or related to, a Salesforce Contact, Account, Lead, or Opportunity.
  • Task - a 'to-do' item related to an Account, Contact, or Opportunity.
  • Note - text entered by a Salesforce user and related an Account, Contact, Lead, or Opportunity.
  • Files - anything uploaded to Salesforce by a Salesforce user.

Accessing the Web-Based Proposal Order Report


Please find below a link to the web-based order report. You will need to be connected to Netextender to access it.


https://orderreport.americanreading.com/summary/134324

 

To navigate to a different order, you can change the â134324â to any opportunity number. 


Below are instructions and a screenshot on how to connect to Netextender:


  1. Open âDell SonicWALL NetExtenderâ
  2. Make sure you have the following server selected: ï»¿âvpn.americanreading.com:4433â
  3. Type your username (firstname.lastname)
  4. Type your password (your standard ARC password)
  5. Make sure the domain is âARCâ
  6. Hit Connect

The Steps of the Proposal Approval Process


In order for an Opportunity to enter the Approval Process, the following conditions must be met:


  • Stage of â2-Designâ or greater
  • Status is âOpenâ
  • Approval Status is empty or âNot Approvedâ


Proposals over $100,000 and/or proposals that include programmatic (e.g. ARC Core) or pilot materials must be approved by both the RVP and the PC. All other proposals can be approved just by the PC.


Once a proposal is submitted for approval, the Approval Status will become âPendingâ and the Opportunity will be locked from editing


If the RVP or PC rejects the Opportunity, it will be sent back to the Account Manager for edits.


If the Opportunity is approved, the customer-facing Proposal can now be downloaded. If the Opportunity is not approved, it will be sent back to the Account Manager for edits.


There is an Approval History card on your Opportunity Page; this is where you can see what step of the process the approval is in. Who it is assigned to, when it was submitted, etc. 

If you have submitted an Opportunity for approval and would like to recall that approval to make edits, you can press the Recall button that will show up on this card as well.

Converting Leads

  1. Find your leads by navigating to the âLeadsâ section of the Salesforce homepage.
  2. Click on the drop-down menu to view all the list options. Select your name or region from the âALL OTHER LISTSâ section. Pro tip: Click on the little pin to make this your default view in Leads.
  3. Once you find a lead who should be a contact, it is easy to convert and assign him/her to the proper accounts. First, click on the leadâs name.
  4. Then review the leadâs information to make sure it is accurate and is formatted correctly. Once everything looks good, select âConverted.â
  5. After hitting âSelect Converted Status,â choose the account it belongs to, select âQualified,â and click âConvert.â

Leads can also be marked as âUnqualified.â Marking âbadâ leads helps us refine our process and lets us know that we should not reach out to them. It will also help you remember which leads you have already reviewed.

When you have identified a bad lead, click on the âLead Statusâ from the table view and select âUnqualifiedâ


For a version of with guide with graphics, please click here.

Adding the Editorial Calendar in Salesforce

  1. From the âCalendarâ tab, click on the gear next to âOther Calendarsâ in the bottom right side of the screen. 
  2. Select âAdd Calendarsâ.
  3. Click on the blue person icon with the dropdown next to it and select âPublic Calendars and Resourcesâ.
  4. Type in âMarketingâ in the search box and select âMarketing Campaignsâ. 

For a version of this guide with graphics, please click here.

Creating Reports

  1. Select the Reports tab, click New Report.
  2. In the Search Report Types, choose the type of report you would like to create. For example, to view your contacts, select "Contacts & Accounts".
  3. Click Continue.
  4. To add fields that you would like to see in your report, click on the "Add column..." field and search for the field you would like to add.
  5. To make sure that youâre viewing exactly what you want to see, select Filters. In Add filter search, you can select things like "Territory State" or "AM"
  6. Click Save, and name your report.
  7. For Folder, select Select Folder and select Public Reports so that everyone can access it. (If you donât want this report to be accessible to everyone, select Private Reports.)
  8. Click Save and then Save & Run.

A Trailblazer guide can be found here.

Adding the Salesforce Sidebar to your Outlook Desktop Program


  • Open Outlook and click on the 'Get Add-ins' icon in the toolbar. If you do not see it, just search 'Get Add-ins' in the search bar at the top of the screen.
  • Click on 'Admin-managed' on the left hand side of the screen that appears.
  • Click the 'Add' button on the Salesforce card.
  • Click on the Salesforce icon that appears in the toolbar. It's a blue cloud.
  • Click on 'Log in'
  • click 'Use Custom Domain' on the login screen.
  • Enter 'americanreadingcompany' in the 'Custom Domain' field.
  • Login using your username/password or by clicking on 'Azure AD SSO'
  • Click 'Confirm' if necessary on the next screen.


You're now set up. Clicking on the pin icon in the Salesforce side panel will keep the sidebar open as you move between emails.

componentInstanceProperties.name: decorate

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
Setting up the Salesforce Mobile App


  • Download the Salesforce app from your phone's App Store.
  • Open it and click 'Use Custom Domain' on the login screen.
  • Enter 'americanreadingcompany' in the 'Custom Domain' field.
  • Login using your username/password or by clicking on 'Azure AD SSO'.
  • Once you're logged in, click on 'App Launcher' and select the 'Sales' option.


You're now set up. The app works just like the desktop webpage. Here are a few notes as you're getting started:


  • The search magnifying glass in the upper-right hand corner searches every tab (e.g. Accounts, Opportunities, etc.
  • If you click on the 'Menu' icon and then 'Edit', you can reorder these items. But any changes you make here will also be changed when you log in on your computer.
